The British artist and philanthropist Harry Hopkins, who died of cancer in 1972 at the age of fifty-six, has been named a finalist in the 2019 Martha Graham Biennial. Born in London in 1942, Hopkins grew up in Liverpool, where he studied at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago. He later attended the Royal College of Art (RCA) in London, where he studied under Henry Aitken, and then attended the RCA in the 1950s. He went on to study in the Netherlands and Germany, where he met and married Anne-Marie Hawes, and in Britain, where he lived and worked for the next twenty-five years, becoming a mentor to some of the country’s most influential artists.While living in Los Angeles in the late 1960s, Hopkins began his legendary journey to create the Flood Sculpture at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, a massive water-reconstruction project that rerouted the work of other artists, including Michael Heizer, John Baldessari, and Robert Irwin, in favor of a single sculpture that was commissioned by the artist.
